title: Ramses: ESA’s mission to rendezvous with asteroid Apophis
summary: Friday the 13th of April 2029 will be our lucky day.
detailed_news: Apophis, a 375-metre-wide asteroid, will safely pass Earth at a distance of less than 32,000 kilometres. For a few hours, Apophis will be visible to the naked eye from Europe and Africa. Space agencies have sent a number of spacecraft to asteroids, but we have never had a mission at an asteroid as it sweeps past a planet.

title: Live coverage: SpaceX to launch final Version 2 Starship-Super Heavy from Starbase
summary: The mission is also projected to be the final launch of the Starship program for the year. Liftoff is scheduled for 6:15 p.m. CDT (7:15 p.m. EDT / 2315 UTC).
detailed_news: SpaceX is scheduled to launch its Starship-Super Heavy rocket from its headquarters in Starbase, Texas, on Monday evening. The 11th flight test of the integrated Starship launch vehicle will be the final mission both for the Version 2 iteration of the rocket as well as the current configuration of Pad A. SpaceX will reuse 24 out of the 33 Raptor 2 engines on B15 during the Flight 11 mission. A commercial lunar lander built by Astrobotic will launch from the Kennedy Space Center on a SpaceX Falcon Heavy rocket in late 2023. Two South Korean Earth-watching satellites will ride Ariane 5 rockets into orbit in 2018 and 2019. Arianespace beat SpaceX in a competition to launch the spacecraft.

title: Starship Flight 11: End of an era, but the beginning of a new one
summary:
After 10 flights, many static fires, tanking tests, cryogenic proof tests, and a few wet…
The post Starship Flight 11: End of an era, but the beginning of a new one appeared first on NASASpaceFlight.com.
detailed_news: Pad 1(A) will be used for the final time for the Starship program in the current configuration. This launch pad has had several different forms over the past few years. It started as a booster test stand, allowing SpaceX to conduct cryogenic tests on Booster 4 and Booster 7. It would go on to host a few more launches until Flight 5, when the chopsticks caught Booster 12, an event that will be remembered forever in space. Ship 38 and Booster 15-2 are the last Block 2 Starship vehicles to fly. Ship 37 redeemed Block 2 of the ship with a very successful mission on Flight 10. The mission objectives for this mission are unchanged from the last four flights, except for an extra test goal for the ship and booster. SpaceX is targeting Oct 13, at 6:15 pm CDT for the 11th flight of Starship. The weather currently looks excellent for launch, with a high of 87°F and low winds. This flight will be bittersweet as Pad 1(A) will be used for the last time in this configuration.

title: What’s Happening in Space Policy October 12-18, 2025
summary: Here is SpacePolicyOnline.com’s list of space policy events for the week of October 12-18, 2025 and any insight we can offer about them. The Senate is in session this week. […]
detailed_news: SpacePolicyOnline.com's list of space policy events for the week of October 12-18, 2025. The week starts tomorrow (Monday) with a Federal holiday, Columbus Day/Indigenous Peoples’ Day. The Senate is in session this week. The House is in recess indefinitely except for pro forma sessions. The House and Senate need to pass FY2026 appropriations bills. The House Appropriations Committee has cleared all 12 bills, albeit on partisan lines. The only D.C.-area event we have on our list is George Washington University’s Scott Pace speaking to the Maryland Space Business Roundtable on Wednesday at lunchtime.

title: Scientists use Cassini data to discover new molecules in Enceladus water jets
summary:
Located around Saturn is the icy moon Enceladus — one of the most interesting and…
The post Scientists use Cassini data to discover new molecules in Enceladus water jets appeared first on NASASpaceFlight.com.
detailed_news: NASA’s Cassini mission extensively studied Saturn and its moons from 2004 to 2017. In 2005, it revealed large geyser-like jets extending from Enceladus’ south pole. Later studies would suggest that a massive subsurface ocean was responsible for the jets. Now, in a new study using archival Cassini data, a team of scientists has discovered a plethora of new complex organic molecules within these jets. The speed at which the ice grains impacted the CDA proved to be important in Khawaja et al.’s analysis. “The ice grains contain not just frozen water, but also other molecules, including organics. At lower impact speeds, the ice shatters, and the signal from clusters of water molecules can hide the signals from certain organic molecules,” says Khwaja.

The post The Netherlands Commits to “Maintain” ESA Contribution Levels Through 2028 appeared first on European Spaceflight.
detailed_news: The Dutch government has decided to contribute €344.3 million to European Space Agency (ESA) over the next three years. With the addition of its national space programmes, the country would spend a total of €550 million from 2026 to 2028. The proposal outlines the country making only a minimal contribution to the agency’s exploration programmes.

title: Ensuring the accuracy of ESA’s FORUM climate mission
summary: The European Space Agency’s upcoming FORUM mission is set to provide unique insights into Earth’s radiation budget, filling in a missing piece in the climate puzzle. The mission’s spectrometer will be the first space-based instrument to measure Earth’s outgoing radiation in the far-infrared part of the electromagnetic spectrum with unprecedented resolution and accuracy. New technologies were needed to make this possible – among these an on-ground calibration device developed by the National Metrology Institute of Germany PTB within a recent activity funded by ESA’s General Support Technology Programme. This device is used to calibrate FORUM’s onboard reference source and ensures the accurate operation of the spectrometer.
detailed_news: The European Space Agency’s upcoming FORUM mission is set to provide unique insights into Earth's radiation budget. The mission's spectrometer will be the first space-based instrument to measure Earth's outgoing radiation in the far-infrared part of the electromagnetic spectrum with unprecedented resolution and accuracy. New technologies were needed to make this possible. Extra temperature sensors will help identify any variations in the measurements. If this proves to be an effective way of detecting degradation, it could become a valuable method applicable to other missions. A twin blackbody, identical to the one in space, would be operated on ground, in conditions resembling space as closely as possible.

title: Completed Plato spacecraft is ready for final tests
summary: By fitting its sunshield and solar panels, engineers have completed the construction of Plato, the European Space Agency’s mission to discover Earth-like exoplanets. Plato is on track for the final key tests to confirm that it is fit for launch.
detailed_news: Plato is on track for the final key tests to confirm that it is fit for launch. The sunshield and solar panels are vital elements for the Plato mission. Once in orbit, the solar array catch light from the Sun to generate the electricity needed to power the spacecraft’s electronics. To spot exoplanets, Plato carries 26 advanced cameras. ESA’s Plato (PLAnetary Transits and Oscillations of stars) will use 26 cameras to study terrestrial exoplanets in orbits up to the habitable zone of Sun-like stars. The spacecraft is being built and assembled by the industrial Plato Core Team led by OHB and Thales Alenia Space and Beyond Gravity.

title: Japan prepares new ISS cargo vehicle as trio of cargo spacecraft deliver new experiments and hardware
summary:
The International Space Station (ISS) recently welcomed three spacecraft that delivered much-needed cargo to support…
The post Japan prepares new ISS cargo vehicle as trio of cargo spacecraft deliver new experiments and hardware appeared first on NASASpaceFlight.com.
detailed_news: The International Space Station (ISS) recently welcomed three spacecraft that delivered much-needed cargo. Progress, Cargo Dragon, and Cygnus spacecraft continue to fly vital missions to keep humanity’s presence in low-Earth orbit going. Japan is also readying its HTV-X cargo spacecraft for its first flight this month. Sierra Space's Dream Chaser, however, is no longer targeted to fly to ISS on its first demonstration mission. The Cygnus XL S.S. launched atop a Falcon 9 from SLC-40 at CCSFS on Sept. 14. This was the first flight of the CygnUS XL version of Northrop Grumman’s cargo spacecraft, featuring an eight-meter-long cargo module. NG-23 carried 5,000 kg of cargo to the Station, including a variety of experiments, as well as the usual selection of hardware and consumables. The HTV-X spacecraft is scheduled to fly on Oct. 20 atop a H3-24L rocket from the Tanegashima Space Center. The spacecraft offers the ability to carry large items of unpressurized cargo that other cargo ships would not be able to fly to the Station. The next launch to the ISS will be the Soyuz MS-28 crewed mission, which is currently set for Nov. 27.  NASASpaceflight.com will take part in the 25th anniversary of NASA's space shuttle program. The program will take place over the course of the next 15 years, starting in 2025 and ending in 2025. NASA will be taking part in a number of events during that time, including a spacewalk.

title: Dancing dust devils trace raging winds on Mars
summary: From the ESA Blogs.
detailed_news: Study was led by Valentin Bickel from the University of Bern in Switzerland. Their catalogue is the first ever to include the speeds and directions of motions for dust devils all over Mars. By tracking how fast the dust devils moved, the researchers found wind speeds of up to 44 m/s. This is faster than we’ve ever measured with rovers on the ground – though it’s worth noting that the martian air is so thin that a human would barely even notice a wind of 100 km/h on Mars. Until now, our models of Mars’s climate have been based on the limited data we have from missions that don’t really cover much of the surface. Thanks to this study, we now have lots of new measurements from all over Mars. This improves our understanding and predictions of wind patterns around the Red Planet.

title: Blue Origin transports New Glenn booster to launch site ahead of Mars-bound mission
summary: The booster named ‘Never Tell Me the Odds’ will support the launch of NASA’s EscaPADE mission, sending two washing machine-sized satellites on their way to Mars.
detailed_news: Blue Origin is one step closer to its second ever launch of its New Glenn rocket. The booster, named ‘Never Tell Me the Odds,’ a nod to the famous line from Star Wars , will be used during the upcoming launch of NASA’s Mars-bound Escape and Plasma Acceleration and Dynamics Explorers ( EscaPADE ) mission. A specific date for that hasn’t been announced, but it's likely in early November. Blue Origin scrubbed the planned launch Tuesday of the company’s suborbital New Shepard booster from West Texas due to a “ground infrastructure issue,” and later said the flight would be pushed back to early 2019. SpaceX and ULA would launch five and two missions respectively as part of the latest round of National Security Space Launch contract assignments.

The post Space infrastructure investments surge to five-quarter high appeared first on SpaceNews.
detailed_news: Global investments in core space infrastructure climbed to a five-quarter high of $4.4 billion. Record activity in the Chinese launch industry contributed to a 12% quarter-on-quarter increase. Defense continues to be the dominant driver in an industry still dominated by the U.S. The highest year on record for infrastructure exits by value remains 2018 with $46 billion across 18 deals, driven by large-scale transactions. 2025 is expected to be the second-highest year for infrastructure exit value and a new high for deal count. title: Satellites reveal the power of ocean swell
summary: During recent storms, satellites recorded ocean waves averaging nearly 20 metres high – as tall as the Arc de Triomphe in Paris and the largest ever measured from space. Moreover, satellite data now reveal that ocean swells act as storm ‘messengers’: even though a storm may never make landfall, its swell can travel vast distances and bring destructive energy to distant coastlines.
detailed_news: During recent storms, satellites recorded ocean waves averaging nearly 20 metres high. This is as tall as the Arc de Triomphe in Paris and the largest ever measured from space. Satellite data now reveal that ocean swells act as storm ‘messengers’. Even though a storm may never make landfall, its swell can travel vast distances and bring destructive energy to distant coastlines. Long swells carry less energy than assumed, while more energy concentrates in the dominant peak waves. This range of wavelengths has been applied to data collected by ESA-developed satellites. Although these waves remain destructive, their true energy dynamics are now better understood. It's like a boxer who, instead of throwing many weak punches, concentrates their power in a few powerful ones.

title: Sabca Secures €85 Million Ariane 6 Operational Phase Contract
summary:
ArianeGroup has awarded an €85 million contract to Belgian aerospace and defence company Sabca for the production of Thrust Vector Control (TVC) systems for 27 Ariane 6 rockets. Sabca and ArianeGroup signed an initial contract for the production of the first batch of Ariane 6 TVC systems in July 2020. The TVC systems allow both […]
The post Sabca Secures €85 Million Ariane 6 Operational Phase Contract appeared first on European Spaceflight.
detailed_news: ArianeGroup has awarded an €85 million contract to Belgian aerospace and defence company Sabca for the production of Thrust Vector Control (TVC) systems for 27 Ariane 6 rockets. The TVC systems allow both the Vulcain 2.1 core-stage and the Vinci upper-stage engine to be steered, providing precise control of the rocket’s trajectory and ensuring stability throughout powered flight.

title: Sentinel-1D preparations underway in Kourou
summary: The Copernicus Sentinel-1 mission is about to get its fourth satellite. Copernicus Sentinel-1D has now undergone the checks and functional tests prior to its integration with Ariane 6, ready for launch later this year.
detailed_news: Copernicus Sentinel-1D has now undergone the checks and functional tests prior to its integration with Ariane 6, ready for launch later this year. When it joins its sibling Sentinel- 1C, which was placed in orbit in December 2024, it will significantly enhance the capabilities of the Copernicus Earth observation programme. Having two satellites in operation at any one time is essential for providing timely data.

title: Rehearsing for Sentinel-6B’s early days in space
summary: Last month, mission controllers at ESA's mission control centre started a major simulations exercise to ensure that the next Copernicus Sentinel Earth Observation mission, Sentinel-6B, safely navigates its first days in space. As the launch is approaching, so is the end of this critical pre-launch phase.
detailed_news: Sentinel-6B is Europe's latest sea-level monitoring satellite. It will be launched by a Falcon 9 rocket from the Vandenberg Space Force Base in California. Mission control at ESA’s European Space Operations Centre (ESOC) is getting ready for the launch. The ‘simulation campaign’ is designed to test the mission control team. A final rehearsal of the countdown and launch sequence will take place at ESOC. During the rehearsal, the mission control team will receive live signals from the satellite via an umbilical connection that will be disconnected shortly before launch. Once this final step is complete, the team will be fully ready to launch Sentinel-6B and give it the GO.

title: Senators spar over plans to move shuttle Discovery
summary:
Efforts to move a shuttle orbiter from the Smithsonian to a Houston museum continues to stir debate among senators amid concerns about the cost and viability of such a move.
The post Senators spar over plans to move shuttle Discovery appeared first on SpaceNews.
